I agree, there could be astronomer villagers, thinning air with heights. You could have cube planets with each of the eight edges being a "great barrier" that complicates game mechanics and gameplay in a way never thought of before. This theme could be an extreme gamechanger. However, one thing that worries me is the tangibility; can a computer process so much data? Does this have any effects on the overworld (it certainly would.)? How would you get between planets? But as I write this, I thought of the End: Islands that are seperated but can be entered via portals; they are right there in the coding! But what if we instead tried a different type of travel; a rocket would certainly not be fitting, but think of something that is! 

I don't know, I'm just pondering all the possibilities; truth is there is an endless amount.

I'm not really a fan of commenting on really old things, but I had a similar idea a while back. Actually, it was the same idea, but the title of the advancement was either "Why Would You Do That?!" or "I've won, but at what cost?", both referencing the fact that you're not supposed to kill it.

Then I remembered the Monsters Hunted advancement exists, and that the death of the Warden would probably count toward that. But that one's really hard.

In that case, this is still a thing that should exist, but it shouldn't award as much as Monsters Hunted.

As for Bedrock, a little character creator item would be fun too, as Oofer0ofs said (that's how I interpreted it).
It'd be nice if the same thing could also be done with many of the partial blocks (such as fences).

iron rusting would be cool, but potentially worrying, however, it would be much slower than copper, oxidizing once every 100-300 Minecraft days, with one more stage than copper. This means that copper will fully oxidize in 240 days on average, while iron will rust in 1000 days on average, the shortest being 500 and the longest being 1500. iron would rust at the same rate as copper when exposed to water, drip particles, or rain.

Maybe the first rusted copper stage (old iron) would be rid of those bothersome borders, (makes it more fun to build with) making iron a smoother block to build with, the second would start the actual rusting.

Iron can also be waxed using honeycomb.
I'm not sure about iron rusting on its own, that kind of takes away copper's unique mechanic. Rusted iron would be a cool texture though. Maybe it could be rusted using dragon's breath?

Maybe it could only be done by direct contact with water in a warm sea biome or with the use of bottles of water, and it would be nice to also be able to slow down the oxidation reaction of the copper block by placing an iron block beside it (because irl iron is more reactive than copper, and the iron would act as a sacrificial metal).
Just to add, they can do this in real life, it's called a Geep and they can have four horns (which is super metal and would make an awesome addition)
Let there be bad mobs protecting the castle treasure
The castle is made of stone/deepslate bricks/brick variations, and illagers (Maybe the chillager) can protect it.
The iceologer could live in the frozen castles

Another way this could work is that, the horn itself would have infinite durability but if used in close proximity to the warden it will break immediately. This eliminates the previously mentioned time limit where instead another horn would be needed to stun the warden again.This idea adds another layer to two of the themes the warden presents being terror and caution.
The Warden is not sound based. It senses movement, not any sounds. It wouldn't hear the sound of a Goat Horn, but rather sense you while you're using it.

@Ziad El-Moursy. The warden senses vibrations. Thatâ€™s why a snowball was used to defer its attention from the player in the trailer at minecon live 2020. It sensed the sound of the snowball. A sound is created when an object vibrates.

That's exactly what I was saying. It doesn't here SOUNDS, like the baaaa of a sheep or the mooo of a cow! It senses movement! It doesn't sense players that are sneaking even though they still make sound, because it is not hearing the sounds, it is sensing significant movement. Given it doesn't hear sounds, it wouldn't be bothered by the extreme noise of a Goat Horn. It will just sense the player when he/she uses it and puts it up to his/her mouth, which is no more severe than the vibration from eating food as it doesn't hear the blow of the horn it self. The Warden is a blind, deaf creature that can feel when something is moving around it. Just try playing a Noteblock next to a Sculk Sensor; it's as if the Noteblock is not even there, because nothing is moving significantly for the Sculk to detect! We have confirmation that Sculk Sensors and Wardens will detect vibrations in the same manner besides a bigger radius for the Warden, so don't say that the Warden might be different. Also according to Kingbdogz, vibrations is not the most accurate word to describe it, rather a general way of saying that it detects movement and not specifically sounds. I know sound is vibrations in real life, but keep real life physics aside for the moment. This is a game.

i dont think they are going to add this they were ingame but they were replaced with emrald but i think that they should at it you could probably creat some sort of jewlery that will give effects? i dont know
great idea by the way.
why do we need a new armor tier?

When they add new ores, they don't just add them for the sake of it. The ores need to serve some unique purpose that make them stand out and make people want to seek them. Quartz, for instance, is used in Redstone components and has unique building variants not existing in other blocks (take pillars, for instance). Some might argue that Copper is not really something you'd want to seek out, but Copper is a new addition. Kingbdogz pointed out that Copper is nothing as useful as Iron because Iron had 10 years to expand and develop. The way he phrased it suggested that they have the intention to expand Copper and make it more useful and worthwhile, so be patient about Copper; it's still very early for it. As for things like Amethysts, yes they are mostly decorative and not particularly exciting, but they have unique mechanics to at least make them a fun enough feature. However, adding an ore purely for decoration doesn't appear to be what they're going for. Even Quartz has some crucial value in Redstone, and like I mentioned, Copper will expand overtime into more than a building block, I'd guess in ways that fit its relation to building and history so that it is still unique. An ore plainly for building is not a good argument, because implementing it as just a block would be more logical in that case.
Mojang already said that we aren't getting more tier tools for now. But they want to add new things like the turtle helmet or the trident which isn't just a new tier tool and armor.
